user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_PthreadTaskEntry:
```c
static void *OS_PthreadTaskEntry(void *arg)
{
    OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t local_arg;

    /* cppcheck-suppress unreadVariable // intentional use of other union member */
    local_arg.opaque_arg = arg;
    OS_TaskEntryPoint(local_arg.id); /* Never returns */

    return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_PthreadTaskEntry:
void OS_TaskEntryPoint(osal_id_t task_id)
{
    osal_task_entry task_entry;

    if (OS_TaskPrepare(task_id, &task_entry) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (task_entry != NULL)
        {
            (*task_entry)();
        }
    }

    /* If the function returns, treat as a normal exit and do the proper cleanup */
    OS_TaskExit();
}
...
static int32 OS_TaskPrepare(osal_id_t task_id, osal_task_entry *entrypt)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        return_code = OS_TaskMatch_Impl(&token);
        *entrypt    = task->entry_function_pointer;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_TaskRegister_Impl(task_id);
    }

    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /* Give event callback to the application */
        return_code = OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_TASK_STARTUP, task_id, NULL);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *entrypt = NULL;
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_TaskExit()
{
    osal_id_t         task_id;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    task_id = OS_TaskGetId_Impl();
    if (OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_TaskDetach_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(OS_SUCCESS, &token);
    }

    /* call the implementation */
    OS_TaskExit_Impl();

    /* Impl function never returns */
}
...
typedef union
{
    void *           opaque_arg;
    OS_ArgCallback_t arg_callback_func;
    osal_id_t        id;
    osal_index_t     idx;
} OS_VoidPtrValueWrapper_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the code after the call to OS_TaskEntryPoint in OS_PthreadTaskEntry is unreachable. OS_TaskEntryPoint invokes OS_TaskExit (which calls OS_TaskExit_Impl) and the implementation is documented to never return, so any statements after that call cannot be reached. Other fragments in the provided code do not contain unreachable code: the union assignment local_arg.opaque_arg = arg is intentionally using a different union member (the id member is later used) and is therefore not dead/unreachable; OS_TaskEntryPoint itself always transfers control to OS_TaskExit (no trailing unreachable statements there); OS_TaskPrepare and OS_TaskExit contain no statements that cannot be reached under any control flow shown. Consequently, no other fragments need investigation for unreachable-code concerns based on the supplied code.
